newsitem.title: USA: SF Fed's Parry says wages may rise at faster pace.
newsitem.headline: SF Fed's Parry says wages may rise at faster pace.

text.p: President of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco Robert Parry said Tuesday wages would probably rise at a somewhat faster pace in the coming months.

Speaking to reporters after an address to to the Rotary Club here, Parry said, "I would think you'll probably see wages rising at a somewhat faster rate. There will be a time when there will be greater pressure on costs for companies and reduction of profit margins."
Parry added that he hopes the nation's economy can avoid "the extreme swings associated with booms and busts."
Turning to inflation, the San Francisco Fed chief said it was "very dangerous" for central bankers not to be on the lookout for inflationary pressures.
However, he hastened to add: "But quite frankly, I don't see any clouds on the horizon in regards to the economy."
As for recent indications of increased productivity, Parry said, "I have my doubts about the exact extent and how long (such increases) are going to continue."
Still, the regional Fed chief said he does not believe data on productivity have changed over the long haul.
Parry also commented briefly on the unemployment rate in the U.S. Joblessness currently is hovering at its lowest level in more than two decades.

"There is some rate of unemployment that if you stay below it for some time, it will cause some inflationary pressure." However, the regional Fed bank president did not qualify what that rate might be.
As for his regional California economy, Parry said the Golden State currently was the ninth fastest growing economy in U.S., which is "impressive" for an economy of that size, he added.
"In general terms, California's numbers look very good," Parry said.
